sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a circular loop
message_1: A circular loop of radius 0.1 m carries a current of 2 A. What is the magnetic field at the center of the loop?
message_2:
To find the magnetic field at the center of the loop, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a current-carrying loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, R is the radius of the loop, and x is the distance from the center of the loop. In this case, we are looking for the magnetic field at the center of the loop, so x = 0.

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * (0.1 m)²) / (2 * (0.1 m)²)^(3/2)

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm * 0.01 m²) / (0.01 m²)^(3/2)

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm) / (0.01 m)

B ≈ 2.5 × 10^(-5) T

The magnetic field at the center of the loop is approximately 2.5 × 10^(-5) Tesla.
